text:
Bernie Sanders wants America to commit suicide to solve a problem that does not exist.  There is no "climate crisis" and there is no "greenhouse gas effect."  Dr. Ned Nikolov and Dr. Karl Zeller used advanced mathematical analysis techniques to study the climates of rocky surfaced planets and moons in our solar system.  They found they could accurately predict their long term average surface temperatures by knowing just two strategic facts: their distance from the Sun and their atmospheric pressure.  This formula has worked correctly for Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, and Pluto, and for Earth’s moon, Europa, Callisto, Titan, and Triton.  Their predictions have been proven accurate to within one degree Celsius.  Like the value of Pi, this mathematical relationship will never go away because it was created by Nature, not by man.  

This means that the specific gaseous composition of the atmospheres of planets and moons are irrelevant to determining their long-term average surface temperatures.  For example, the atmosphere of Venus is composed of 96.5% carbon dioxide, while Earth’s atmosphere contains only .04% carbon dioxide, yet that information was not even needed to predict temperature.  The logical conclusion is that atmospheric gases only contribute to warming by their physical mass, which increases atmospheric pressure.  For links to scientific details, please see New Climate Discovery at
http://renewable.50webs.com/Zeller.Nikolov.html

See discussion of the ongoing NASA and NOAA data faking scandals at 
https://twitter.com/nikolovscience

For deep background climate science details, see Video Tutorial Cures Climate Hysteria at http://renewable.50webs.com/Video-Tutorial.html

text:
Biden isn't for single-payer-healthcare, he isn't for a green new deal, and he isn't for ending the wars, and he has history of supporting racists. He's Trump with folksy charm. In some ways he's worse than Trump, in that he would support the same policies, but he'd be able to silence opposition by being likable and by appealing to party-unity, "party-unity" just being a bullshit word for "compliance." 

His policies would hurt the working class, while getting people killed for the profits of the weapons industry, and moving the planet closer to being unlivable for humans. 

He's not meaningfully different from Trump, and his policies will provoke a backlash that will result in another Trump-type getting elected in four years. People are gong to hate Biden and want a real change, but since the only alternative will be some Republican demagogue of the worst sort, that's what they will vote for. 

So this idea that Biden is somehow the pragmatic choice is bullshit. To vote for Biden is to sell your soul for absolutely no gain. To vote for Biden is to vote for a folksy, likable Trump followed by a total Trump in four years. 

Vote for someone who will fight for single-payer-healtcare, ending the wars, and a green new deal. It's both the principled choice AND the pragmatic choice.  Vote for Bernie Sanders.

text:
​ @Benjamin Selassie  Some responses to your last two comments:
- Yes, some workers do own some, and a few own all of a company and that's fine.  Rewarding stock is standard practice - but the Fed'l Gov't isn't allowed to SEIZE it permanently.


- Gov't can tax / regulate activities like off-shoring to influence decisions, but Bernie is banning it.  E.g. It's poor economic policy to raise super-high tariffs on all trade willy-nilly, but this is more akin to just cutting off trade.  Competing and capitalism require a level playing field, not extreme protectionism.


- Healthcare is certainly in need of reform, but M4A is not the panacea it has been described to be.  Actually executing it as a project has to be done through trialing (like medical treatment, eh?), never mind financially vetted.  Bernie's been blowing smoke up everyone's gastrointestinal tract.


As pitched, almost all technological development in medicine would cease - and I don't know about you, but I was hoping for solutions to cancer, Alzheimers, diabetes, etc.  


The relatively tiny ACA couldn't even get a simple web site right, plus gobs of their justifications and assumptions were just plain wrong.  M4A is a 60% INCREASE IN THE FED'L GOV'T!  Based on the delays and massive cost overruns of VIRTUALLY EVERY Gov't project in the past (Remember the $700 military hammers?), what could possibly go wrong?


- I'm all for infrastructure spending, if done judiciously (e.g. updating bridges and highways).  But mandating that we tear down almost every building to improve its energy use is ludicrous.  Just the act of doing that will likely lead to a net rise in carbon use across the globe to say nothing of the unjustifiable (and HUGE) expense.  Maybe after we simply stop bridges from collapsing and potholes from swallowing Smart cars, we could consider doing a bit of the infrastructure work that was naively outlined in the GND. 


- Minimum wage should go up, but $15/hr in Los Angeles and $15/hr in Podunk, Mississippi are two vastly different things.  Since it's federal, the amount should be at the low end so rural Mom 'n Pop stores can afford to exist and hire more people.  States and cities should adjust accordingly.  But, yeah, time to raise it some.


- Interestingly, as you allude to, Bernie used to be very much like Trump on immigration issues - strong border and lots of protectionism against immigrants (legal and illegal) "stealing" Americans' jobs.  He either had an epiphany, or a political change of heart, and that's why he's almost Mr. Open Borders with consequent Hispanic support.  


Personally, I believe we need many more immigrants, as they can be the life-blood of innovation in "the land of opportunity."   I am, however, in favor of being more selective by skill to some degree, rather than simply by having relatives here.  Illegal immigration needs to be gotten under control and not rewarded every generation with citizenship.


"The Middle Class" are the people who actually pay a net positive in taxes and are not the top couple %.  They will be burdened with all these massive spending programs Bernie has dangled out there in the name of democratic socialism, because, as Willie Sutton said, "That's where the money is."  You may trust Bernie to spend all of your money, but I don't.


Getting rid of Trump is an imperative, not just because he's a menace at the job, but because he's a narcissistic sociopath with no redeeming qualities whatsoever.  However, it's nice to know our system/country is so strong that it could abide the reign of such an affliction.  We could (probably) survive Bernie too.

This isn't a problem that gets solved by more immigrant to be the working class. We have to change how we think of our own people and how we think of ourselves.

text:
Socialism fails wherever tried because it is committed to faulty method. Socialism deals not with reality but with ideas - idea of “humanity as a whole” or with other “holistic” concepts “food”, “housing”, “healthcare”, “education” as opposed to degrees. Such concepts are not things but ideas advertised as things. Commodities or things minus prices are not things but ideas in your head. Socialism cannot work because its goal is removal of the corner stone of real things: prices, conditions to entry or "barriers to access". Healthcare without prices which cover cost of production over time is not healthcare but negation of healthcare, ideology of healthcare. Prices or conditions are not external to healthcare, not “impurities” or “pollution” in healthcare but healthcare in itself. Prices of healthcare ARE healthcare. Prices are the nature of healthcare. Prices of healthcare are the universal healthcare. Healthcare not connected to producers by prices is not healthcare. Healthcare independent of conditions of time & place, that is, healthcare outside space & time is not real healthcare but gap in healthcare, idea, ideology in reality, Muller Healthcare. 
In this way Socialism is not responding to reality bc it is not responding to people. People don’t want “food”, “housing”, “healthcare”, “education” . People want things in time & place, namely, people want very specific & particular [read: ‘unequal’] degree, kind, quality, quantity etc of food or house or education or healthcare at every point in time. The opposite of “Free” are “prices”. Prices are signals to producers what people actually want to consume at a given [“unequal”]  time & place. The miracle of prices informs producers about all that they need to know to respond to people’s actual demand & maintain that response over time. Prices tell producers who wants what, when, where, how much or up to what point. Prices consumers send to producers about their desires is the most vital element in people. Without prices there is no people bc there is no production for the people. “Food”, “housing”, “healthcare”, “education” without prices are not commodities but concepts. No one ever wants “food” or “education” or “healthcare”. Those are ideas of idealists, not things people in time & place actually ask for. text:
@Raspberry Brambles  You're the one dreaming.

"Without question, Mr. Sanders’s margin right now in California is a big deal. But let’s take a closer look at two states that have shown big political shifts toward Democrats in the Trump era: Virginia and Texas.

In both states, turnout was up on Tuesday.

In Virginia, 1.3 million people voted, a huge increase from the 780,000 votes cast in the state’s 2016 Democratic primary.

In Texas, more than 2.1 million ballots have been counted with 99 percent of precincts reporting. That’s up from 1.4 million votes four years ago.

Yet, Mr. Sanders again lost both states — and captured smaller shares of the vote than in 2016.

That year, Mr. Sanders won 33 percent of the vote in Texas. This year, he got only 30 percent. In Virginia, he fell from 35 percent in 2016 to 23 percent in 2020."

--- New York Times 'On Politics'

text:
@liberal slayer  You do not have the temperament of a medical professional. But seeing as I can't prove whether you are or not, I will tell you what I do know.


I have been to the hospital more than 20 times in my life. I have been to hospitals in more than four provinces, the largest being Ontario and the smallest being Prince Edward Island.


Allow me to tell you about the most notable instances.


1. Broken arm - I fell off a deck and snapped my wrist. My dad drove me to the emergency room.
I was admitted within 10 minutes. I received a temp-plaster cast and pain medication.
Following a 1 hour wait, I was brought back in to get an X-Ray. Following the X-Ray I was immediately fitted for a cast.


Total Bill: $2.00 for a bag of chips.


2. Allergic Reaction & Severe Anxiety Attack - Picked up by an ambulance. Admitted immediately. Treated immediately. Discharged after 6 hours of excellent care.
Total: $40.00 for the ambulance ride. 


3. Sprained Thumb - dropped a dumbbell on it. Was seen to by a triage nurse. Given pain meds. Waited 4 hours. 
Received an X-Ray. Waited 2 hours for results.
Given a small thumb splint. Thumb was concluded to be not broken.
Total: $0.00


We are not overtaxed. We pay the same taxes as you actually.


Our healthcare is excellent.


Our pharmaceutical drugs are affordable.


There are no lines. You are so tone deaf you actually believe we make our patients stand in a physical line.


Thousands of Americans die each year as a result of not being able to access affordable healthcare. Millions are uninsured.


Meanwhile, I've paid less than $50.00 over the course of 23 years.


There is a lot more wrong with America. I am proud to be Canadian.
